oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Franklin College campus
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Agriculture -- Tennessee; Fanning, Tolbert, 1810-1874
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of the agricultural school known as Franklin College illustrates the buildings present and the lay-out of the campus. From the book, "Franklin College and Its Influences," by James E. Scobey.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Scobey, James E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tolbert Fanning, a leading Disciple of Christ and advocate of scientific agriculture, founded Franklin College in 1845 on the grounds of his farm at the present-day site of the Nashville International Airport. The agricultural school focused on classroom scientific study of agricuture, horticulture, and the mechanical arts; manual application in the fields; and religious study. Disrupted by the Civil War, the college was to reopen after the conflict, but was destroyed by fire.
